transcript.content: Gregory Alcindor_Transcription REDACTIONS FINAL

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Well my name is Gregory Alcindor, I was 18 years old at the time I committed this crime. I did 31 years. This 31 years today, this year is going 31 years.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And what was the crime that you were convicted of?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: 1st degree murder.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, I want to start. I want to learn about you and I want to start by asking you some questions about your time before 18 and then we'll switch gears a little bit and then look at circumstances of the actual crime but mainly, I'd like to focus on your time here at Angola since then. So, can you start by telling me a little bit about your family, the folks that raised you?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Well my family was a Christian family. My mother she was like a wine, she used to drink a lot and so my grandmother, my grandfather, took us and I stayed in the house next door. I was going to school, I dropped out of school because I used to get in trouble a lot in school, and I wanted to do things, something to provide for my younger sisters and brothers, so that's what made me picked up the gun.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, so what about, let's go back before that a little bit. So your grandparents primarily raised you?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And siblings you mentioned. So tell me about your siblings. How many and where are you in the birth order?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: What you mean?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So how many siblings do you have? And where are you in the birth order? Like were you the oldest child?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I'm the second to the oldest.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, tell me who they are. Who are you?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Well, there's Carl Alcindor, there's me, Gregory Alcindor, there's Lamada Alcindor, there's Tahara Alcindor, there was Kendra Alcindor, but Kendra she died in 2001. She had a tumor on her brain.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So there are 4 of you now.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: There's four of us.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and are your grandparents still alive?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yes one Ms. Deretha Jones.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And are you still close with her?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yes, I am close to her. Yeah, we talk.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: All right, what about your mother?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: My mother passed right after I got this time. In '87 yes sir when I was 18.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So you were quite young. And was that alcohol related?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yes sir. Alcohol, yes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What about your father? Did you know your father?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I know my father but there was off and on and then they wasn't staying together.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, alright. Do you have any kind of relationship with him now?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: No, he passed in 2012.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. Now what about your siblings? Your remaining 3 siblings. Are you still in touch with them?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yes sir, I am in touch. I talk to my sister and my youngest brother.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, all right, so let me ask you this. Of all of the folks that you knew growing up, who would you say you have the closest relationship? The person who really understood you the best?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I would say maybe friends.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, just someone who really got you.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I would say my best friend David Hooper. That's who comes see me Sunday. We brothers from childhood. Yeah, I guess I would say him. Before that, family wise I could say my Uncle Clarence Jones, he, Clarence.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay so and so is he somebody he took an interest in you, when you were young?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yeah, he keeps me in line, tell me to stop doing bad things.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay this is your mother's brother?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: That's my momma's brother.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Alright. Now tell me where did you grow up. I know you said you're from Jefferson Parish.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I grew up in Marrero, Louisiana.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, where about in Marrerro?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: On Marrerro.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That's where you went to school I presume. So tell me a little bit about school?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Well, I was going to Marrero Middle.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. Did you like school? Were you good in school?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I was because I liked the school, I was good in school but, there were a couple of fights. That's going on any teenager. I had to quit school because I had to really look out for my sisters and brother, the ones under me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, did you have a memory of a specific memory of a teacher who took an interest in you? Teacher who you remember?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I forgot all my high school teachers.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That's fine. What was the highest year of school that you completed?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I went to 9th.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, all right. So, I know where Marrero is but I'm not very familiar with it. I live in New Orleans. But, can you paint a picture a little bit for me, so what year were you born?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: We're, kind of the same age, so let's go back to when we are both 17. I was 16 and let's say we're sitting on your front door step, okay? So can you paint a picture for me? What's going on in the neighborhood? What do you see?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Well, I see a lot of people outside there. It's you be seeing? You might probably see nice girls passing by. It really wasn't on that side, it really wasn't bad violence at that age. There was a lot of girls. Everybody run by girls, talk to them and stuff like that. Play with our little cousins and stuff. That's about it though.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, sort of quiet neighborhood?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: It was a quiet neighborhood.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you see a lot of fighting in the neighborhood?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yes, fights like in Villa James, but not every day but you had fights.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you find yourself getting into fights?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Not really. I wasn't really a messy person. I wasn't the person, fella starting it. I probably try to walk away really, I'm not trying to be no violent person. I try to walk away, but if a person keep picking at me, or something, then I'll have to fight him or if he hit me, I'll probably have to fight him.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about some of your memories with this friend of yours that you mentioned earlier.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Oh man. When we was young, we used to have fun. We would we used to play, we used to.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I assume you knew each other since elementary school.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Right. We know each other since elementary, we went to elementary school. Name is Franklin. I don't know if she's still living in that. That was in West Jeff Elementary and we did a lot of things. We used to take the people's watermelons and stuff. Yeah, we used to, have fun as kids, don't mean to hurt nobody or nothing, but we had fun riding our bikes and stuff. Run across the tracks. Playing baseball and stuff together.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did he end up getting in trouble at all?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: He got into trouble before but I don't know when it was. He wasn't, he got locked up for selling drugs or something. But he been out about 15 years now. I haven't seen him here in a long time. He came to the Rodeo last year in October and that's when I met him after all these years. He told his wife that he was coming. He was coming to Angola to Rodeo to find me and he found me and when he found me, I seen him, I said, "This got to be God. This can't be nobody but God doing this." So yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So you had no idea he was coming, he just walked in, he really said "Gregory." That's a nice thing to happen. So, did you ever get kicked out of school?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Me, I got kicked out. He got kicked out. He used to do a lot of fighting, but over the year he matured and got back.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. Okay, so what about girlfriends. You were mentioning. We were on that stoop we'd be seeing a few pretty girls.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I had lots of them. I had a girlfriend. I had girls, just give me one but I already had a girl.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, sure, well is there anyone that sticks out in your memory? Special Someone?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yeah. A got a couple of them. Miss Viola Guns, Viola. My ex-wife Tanya Smith, Deidre Williams.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Of all of these folks, sorry, I didn't mean to catch you off, Kim? Of all of those folks, who stands out in your mind as that special someone?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Mostly, my ex-wife Tanya Smith, yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and you were married after you were incarcerated or before?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I got married after I was incarcerated. I got married in Angola in 19th March 20, 1998.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and is this somebody that you knew before or somebody you met after?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: This is somebody that I met out the club in '87 that I ain't got in touch with back with her in like the late 90s, in the late, we got married. I met her in about '95, '96 in a banquet up here and seen her since '87 and we started talking, communicating and stuff and got back together and then we got married up here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay in '98 and then how long were you married?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Let's say about 9 years, we got divorced in 2007.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, can you tell me a little bit about how that works? How do you obtain a marriage when you're incarcerated?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Oh man. Keep your faith, I mean, hope that she won't ever leave. But you got to give her space because she's free. She can leave at any time. But, I don't know man. It's just.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I think you know so you're basically just visits, I imagine she would come up here and visit you.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: She come and visits, visit twice a month, come to banquets, come to the Rodeo, spend time the hard thing is when they're leaving. At that point because you ain't going home with her. It has a big effect on her too.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, I would imagine it's difficult for everybody. I mean, marriage is hard enough without those things. So, you mentioned children earlier on can you tell me a little bit about children that you have?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Well, my children was young, and my Kevin was, my son, Kevin, he was like 6 months. And my step-daughter Mica and Jermain and Tamika was about 2. Teisha was about, I'd say about 3. Jermaine was about 5.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yes sir, but I adopted one named Tamika.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay as a step son?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: As a step daughter.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Step-daughter, I'm sorry and so tell me about Kevin. What's he doing?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Well Kevin, he's a wonderful son. I'm so proud of him. I mean, he got. He was working at a big ole plant in Texas, Pull-off in Texas. He's 31 now, born September 26, 1987. He got 4 kids. 3 by one woman, 1 by another lady. He what I like to say, he working at a plant, but he- the plants sometimes give layoffs so you going to get laid off, but he's a wonderful dad. He takes full responsibility for. At least one or two of them with him. Oh man, he's doing things I want to do with him when he was a kid.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Have you been able to be somewhat of a father to him over the years?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Well, I had too long got back in contact with him because he was in Texas, and I didn't have his mother's phone number. We been back together about in contact about 3, 4 years now.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That's a long time without.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Well, I didn't see my son since he was 10. Now he can't get on my visiting list because response at his record.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, but that made him ineligible to be on your list.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yeah, to come see me. I can't put him on my visit. I can't get nothing for that. That would show up on the record.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. Were you and your son keep in touch through letters?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Well, not when he was younger because I didn't have his information. Now I have his information. I have his home number and his address.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: When was the last time you saw him?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Gregory #00:15:26-3#:Since he was 10. I got pictures if you see them, he's a grown man. Got dread locks, good Dad, so I'm proud of him.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And you've never seen your grandchildren.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I seen not in person but I've seen them in pictures. Pictures I have.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you have any desire, plans to maybe try to organize a visit with them?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yes, I just put, his mother visit me because she moved back to Texas. I'm just putting my step daughter, Tamika the one I adopted and her kids so basically, they'll probably come see. Might come around next month sometime. I'd glad when I see them, but I don't see them man.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I ain't never seen none of them or hold them since they've been born, so I'd love to do that if I have time. Hopefully once I get out so I can spend time with them, bring them to the park, be a grandfather, something I want to be. I couldn't be a dad so now I'm hoping I can get a chance to be a grandfather, spend time with them.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: No, that makes sense. So, one of the first things that you said when I asked you about the folks who raised you was that you were living with your grandparents and one thing led to the other and you felt because nobody was taking care of your siblings that you felt the need to sort of step up and do that and you said that's what led you to pick up a gun.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, let's go explore some of that for a minute. So, can you tell me about the first time you got arrested, do you remember that?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I got arrested in '86 for a possible burglary, simple charges. I didn't do no time. The only thing I did was like 2 year probation. I never did no DLC time or Parish time something like that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And then, you're 18. You're a kid. All of a sudden, you're facing a 1st degree murder charge. I don't know anything about it. Can you just give a brief summary? As I said, I don't really need to get into the details of it. I'm just trying to see what the story is.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I caught a first degree murder charge, I was like man. I was in shock because I was like well, I was really robbing a lady

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you remember the race of this woman?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: She was white lady about, she was about like, I want to say about 20-21.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Where was this?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: It was in New Orleans, in Marrero. It was like off of Canal Street. I might be saying the street wrong.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You were just trying, it was a robbery. So because it was a robbery, it becomes a first degree murder charge. And so were you arrested right away or?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: No, they picked me up like after like a week after, a week or two after.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You're 18 years old and I imagine that you spend a little bit of time in the parish as you go through this trial, first degree murder trial. Did you realize how serious it was at the time?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yes. I was like man, I'm about to die, definitely. I don't know what the outcome is going to be, I'm scared. I really won't talk to nobody in the parish, because I don't know nobody. I from Jefferson Parish. I was staying with a girlfriend over there on the east side somebody I met. I'm scared. I don't know what to do.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How much time passed in the Parish before you were convicted?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I don't know it was like. I got busted in February. I went to trial in October. October '87.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and so you're 19 when you come up to Angola?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yes sir. I come March the 28, 1980.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you remember the bus ride coming down here?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Oh yeah, man. The road used to be, look like a snake road with big old hole and rocks in it. It wouldn't even like it wasn't like that like it is now.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Can you, for a minute, can you go back in time there and just what's going through your head as you're arriving down here?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I don't ever, I'm like I don't ever going to get out of Angola. I don't know nobody in Angola, I might wind up killed in here or something, I don't know. I think, man my day's about this lady every day. I wish I could give her half of my life. Just to see how people, sick and tired of people.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, I understand. I imagine that you were scared. And all kinds of stories about Angola. Any of those stories end up being true?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yes. Man.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about that?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: = #00:21:16-3# Well it's just that I don't know, I figuring it out, doesn't know what happens

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: / #00:21:30-2# Yeah, you no, I understand that and I'm going to ask you about that here in a minute too. If it's on your mind right now, let's talk about it. So, it's been 30 years. I mean, that is a lifetime and, I think it's difficult if I try to think about something that happened 30 years ago in my life, it's so distant that sometimes it's difficult to connect to that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: When you look back, and for you it was this defining moment because it's set the rest the rest of your life on track right? So when you look back on it now, 30 years later, about the victim, what happened, what are you? How do you feel? I can honestly can see that you feel upset about it? What are your thoughts about it now?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I'm sorry. Sorry for the crime I committed.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I know one of the things that happens when these things happen is that obviously, there's the obvious victim, who's the person, and then their family, but there's usually a much wider pool and in some cases your family your loved ones are victims too. If you look at your own family, who do you think took it the hardest, having to watch you come up here?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I would say my mother, my children, my grandmother, my sisters, everybody that was under me, was young.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. What about your uncle, you mentioned that he was kind of this commemorated person in your life. How did he take that?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: He took it hard too, because he's trying to guide me right. I talked to him last week. He down there with some type of cancer. But he told me, he's all right. He's going to be all right, don't worry.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So much time has passed. Gregory, have you forgiven yourself?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Man, I guess I forgive myself for doing this, but I want to let the people know, the victim's family, how sorry I am for taking their child's life. Like, something that was an accident, should never happen.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: . So, one of the reasons that we're, we want to talk to folks like yourself is that, again, this is this event that happens very early in your life, obviously very serious event and but the vast majority of your life has been since then, and it has been in this institution and nobody is the same person 30 years later. And I'd like to learn a little bit about some of the changes that you've been through since you've been here. So, let me start by asking you, can you describe the Gregory Alcindor that came into the gates of Angola? Like that 19 year old kid just describe that kid for a minute and then I want you to tell me how different you are from that kid now.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Young scared, I don't know nobody here. Don't know anybody in jail because Angola was a penitentiary, now it has changed over the years. I mean, I was getting in trouble. I didn't want to listen to the officers and stuff, that's when I first come.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you get a lot of write-ups?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I got 56 write-ups in 30 years. I really don't try to play them write ups because a write up really can hurt you in the long run if you trying to go on the board, any type of board and stuff. I just got 56 write ups.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, but were most of them when you first came here?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Most of them were when I first came here. Most of them are low call write-ups.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, and that's a pretty normal pattern. Almost everybody's like that. So what kind of were you, you said you weren't listening to the officer, would you find yourself getting into a lot of fights?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Not with no officer. I ain't had that many fights up here with inmates either, I had a lot of altercations with officers, talking. They cursed you out, I'm cursing them back out, but I never did fight or nothing with no officer.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, in those 30 years, what do you think the most significant changes have been for you? And as I've said, we're all different.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Over the years, I got my trustee status. I wanted to do right. I wanted to start difference making these people because these nothing. I got myself here. So now I got in on classes, to get certificates and stuff.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I try to help other inmates, especially the ones that are in wheelchairs and stuff like that and can't help themselves. I try to help them. I try to buy them something to eat, if they don't have money. I try to give them bars of soap or something. Deodorant if they don't have it. Go to church you need Jesus everybody needs Jesus. I try to walk around the yard with them, go sit by their bed, talk to them and let them know that it's going to be alright.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, can you tell me, you're describing some things that maybe you might have been a part of some organizations like, are you with for example hospice or Medical Orderlyor, can you tell me of some of the clubs and organizations that you've been in or what are some of the jobs you've had?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Well, I used to work at the hospital on the ward, then I got a trustee job but I got my 100 hours, my Anger Management, my Substance Abuse. I'm in school. I go to church. I go to Pastor Ryan, his church. When I was, but I'm moving to Camp F. I'm doing certificates. I'm doing certificates on I'm doing the Bible College from Baton Rouge, Thinking for a Change. I'm about to get in that class back at F1, the new call out. I'm just trying to stay into something positive.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, no, it sounds like you're doing all of those things. Have any of those experiences that you've had at Angola, do any of them stand out as being the most important in terms of changing who you are, changing your perspective?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yeah I'm trying to think well, once I got baptized up here at Angola and married, I just thought it was time for a change, man. I'm getting older, and time passes in years and don't know when I'm going to get out of here. It's a lot to think about, so you got to really just worship God man, ask him for forgiveness.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. Let me ask you a little bit more about this and I realize that this is a difficult conversation to have but I also think that it's really important. When you're helping some of these older guys right in wheelchairs as a medical orderly but even as opening up your eyes and looking around this place, you see people who die here, and where life means life until you die.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So I want to try to understand how people cope with that. I mean, so when you're confronting with the reality of what you just said, "I might never get out of here" how do you cope?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I mean, I just take it one day at a time, thanking the Lord for waking me up. I see a lot of guys die here. I've seen a guy got killed in here. You can't get really in people's business but I try to stop it, just mind your business. So if I did, that I mind their business. I tried to help a lady that name Candy Pokes, she got a heart attack in the dorm back then in Falcon 1 and I tried to save her life, I tried.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I see she was breathing. I caught her before she hit the floor, lay on the floor, the other guy's going to knock on the door to try to get the free man's attention, so once he got the freeman's attention, he still on the phone. So she had a beeper on her on her chest, I got the beeper and I hit it.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: And that's when the other big red and major and all of them come running in there asking, "What's wrong, What's wrong?" I said sit on the floor. They telling me to get back, get back, I said I got back, just trying to figure out what happened to her. I don't know man, she was about to fall out the chair, I was by the sink washing my bowl and I see her. And I jump across the counter, trying to catch her before, she was hitting her head and I laid her on the ground.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: And they come and the call and ambulance and they're doing CPR on her but, I mean, looking at the lady, I already know she's dead. Dead, he's talking about, she wasn't dead. She was dead. She died right there on that floor. I'm looking at.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Wow, is she a security?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Gregory #00:32:52-6#:A security lady. A security officer.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Wow. Were you afraid that they might think that you had something to do with it?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Well, yeah, I was scared but everybody like the whole dorm was already still up.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, so there were a whole bunch of people in there.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yeah, a lot of people were in there, so they can't say I did it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I got you. Yeah and I think, when you do see people dying in here, it's just one of those reminders that we're all I mean, we're all going to die, but again, it's the question of like how that's going to happen. It sounds to me that you're also somewhat of a religious person. Is that another way of coping with that?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yeah I do, I like to help people. If I can help you, I'm going to help you.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. Can you take a minute and just describe your typical day here like the minute you get up in the morning, what's your routine until you go to bed?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I just, when I get up in the morning, I brush my teeth, wash my face and I sit there and I thank I thank the Lord for getting me to see another day. I put my clothes on, I head to wait and to see the Lieutenant needs me to do anything, if he don't, I just walk around the camp and I go work at the club called I work in and I just sit there, hoping to have a good day. I might go get a book or something, look at, I read. And I just go the day out.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay are you reading a book right now?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: No. I'm thinking.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, you had mentioned earlier that you got Baptized here and you got married here and that you just decided there's got to be a better way, right, change some. Was that the turning point in your life here at Angola? Or was it what made you turn around and just say I got to do something different?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Well, I had this that came in my life. Her name was Alice Sanders. She is, her son's adopted, so she adopted me and I'm talking about while I was in jail, I mean, and she's still an officer right now. And she really was the one that turned me around to God, and ever since then I've been following that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you remember when this happened?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I was in like about I've been knowing this Alice, like 18 years now so I can say like about 2008. 2006 something like that but, yeah she been there ever since. When I call her, she comes see me. She's the one that told me to turn my life around. It don't take one day, it might take a while but it did happen. And I surprised her with that Baptism.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: When were you Baptized?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I know it was in March I believe like '95, '96 somewhere around that I believe. I got married '98. March 20th 1998.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So all of that happened before you met her? You got baptized and married and you met her?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Well, no Miss Alice, I met her first, then I got baptized, then I got married.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay got it. So she was responsible for some of those things.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, so let me ask you this. You, everybody at some point, if you live long enough here, no matter what, you become eligible to apply for clemency from the pardon board. Do you have plans to do that?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yes sir. I'm about to file for clemency in September.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and when you do come before the pardon board, they'll have all of your information, somebody will have done an investigation on your case. They'll have your jacket and various other things.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yeah, I'm from Camp F.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So when you come before the Pardon Board, I don't know if you've heard about it but, there's a group of folks who, 5 people usually who are sitting behind this bench kind of thing and then they'll be here at Angola and they'll be linking you up together. And you'll have a short period of time when some folks will speak for you, and then you can speak for yourself. What would you want them to know about you?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: I would like to go in front of the board and commit my sorry first for the victim, I ask the board to give me another chance. Get me free and I know I can be all that and help change my community, help try to raise my grandkids, just give me the opportunity to have a chance. I ain't coming back.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, so, I think obviously there's a lot of negative aspects about being in prison, obviously. And I think it may change depending on the time, when you first come in there are some things that are worse than others and then there are certain things where you find your place and stuff. What's the worst part of being in prison for you now?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: The worst part. Man, you don't know you're get out. You don't know when you're going to get out of prison

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So just, living with the thoughts that this might never end, is that the thing that you're saying?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yeah. This might never get out. Might never get out to go be with your family spend time with kids and grandkids.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you think all of that would change if you were given a date? Let's say you were given a date, I don't know, 10 years from now. Do you think living with at least a date in mind would help?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Yeah. Yeah it would help.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, that makes sense. Let me ask you this Mr. Alcindor, of all of the things that you've accomplished and you've told me about quite a few of them and that's impressive given that you're here doing all these things, but what are you most proud of?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: Most proud of, giving my life to God. And making it through here these 31 years because I've seen a lot of stuff happen here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. I understand. Is there something that I should have asked you? As I said, I'm trying to capture your experiences here but also learn about you as a person. Is there something that you wanted to talk about that we didn't talk about or something that I should have asked you that I didn't?

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: You really asked everything. I'm glad you did.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Good, well, I wanted to thank you very much for doing this, I mean, I know you've got other things to do and I appreciate you taking the time. It's very valuable for us. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: Gregory
transcript.content: You're welcome.
